key_points: Prosecutors in Derek Chauvin's trial have adjusted the duration of time Chauvin's knee was on George Floyd's neck to about nine minutes.
The time initially recorded was 8 minutes, 46 seconds, but was later corrected to 7:46 due to a math error.
Recent filings, citing police body-camera video, have now adjusted the duration to at least nine minutes.
The discrepancies in the timing are not expected to impact Chauvin's trial, according to a former prosecutor and a support group for victims of police violence.
Derek Chauvin is charged with second-degree murder and manslaughter for the death of George Floyd.
Three other officers are charged with aiding and abetting second-degree murder and manslaughter, scheduled for trial in August.
The 8:46 timing became symbolic, prompting demonstrations and acts of remembrance lasting 8 minutes, 46 seconds.
Prosecutors acknowledged a one-minute error but stated it would not affect the case.
The revised timing from prosecutors indicates Chauvin's restraint lasted at least nine minutes but possibly up to 9 minutes, 31 seconds.
The exact duration of the restraint is anticipated to be a significant part of the trial, relating to Floyd's cause of death and Chauvin's state of mind.
spokespersons: Toshira Garraway (Founder, Families Supporting Families Against Police Violence)
